There was some number crunching that went into this. First, it is important to note the popular vote as a way to gauge where Trump started off in terms of popularity. It can be assumed that on election day, roughly all 62 million Trump voters would have said they approve of him as a president. So, this would put Trump at a 48.8% approval rating. Between now and then, his rating has sunk down to 45%. Of the remaining population, 45% disapprove and 10% are undecided. Based off of his antics, stances on divisive issues and overall presence, it is unlikely Trump will convince those who already dislike him, to begin to approve of him as a president. However, it is not entirely impossible, which is why there is a 5% chance that Trump will have a +15 net approval. Of those who are undecided, there are a few possibilities. I expect there to be three potential splits - 7% approve and 3% disapprove, 5% approve and 5% disapprove, 3% approve and 7% disapprove. My best guess is that the last option is most likely. The nation mostly belongs to the Democratic party, and Trump doesn't do himself any favors by staying out of the spotlight. So, with the undecided population now decided, the split comes out to a 52% disapprove, 48% approve. This is a net of -4%. This gap could further widen to a 57% disapprove and 43% approve split with a margin of -14%. In other words, Trump would need to lose the support of 3,148,994 people which is roughly the population of Iowa. This is not people that already dislike him - Trump would need to under perform so badly that 3 million of his own supporters would feel the need to reject him. That is a substantial amount, and not one to be taken lightly. However, the political landscape is becoming a minefield. Trump is going to oversee the repealing of Obamacare and sign its replacement into law. In order to live up to campaign promises, it will have to be nothing short of stellar. Speaking of campaign promises, that list has yet to be touched, which could make his voting base start to feel resentful. These factors could play into a substantial loss of support for Trump. As such, this is why I have put the final split of odds for Trump at a 25% chance he has a net approval of -15, 70% that he has a net of -15 to +15 (inclusive), and 5% that he has a net of +15.
